results.notes:
Code: Bot_1111/2018_DSC0872

Habitat: narrow canyon; stony, vertical, calcareous, manmade supporting wall; north aspect; very humid place with no sun most of the year; in total shade; about 1.5 m above the mountain stream; exposed to direct rain; average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 8-10 deg C, elevation 470 m 1.530 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: calcareous rocks of a vertical wall of a bridge over a mountain stream.

Place: Bovec basin, at the mouth of Bavščica valley; near the destroyed water mill on Šumnik stream; East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC

Comments: Gyalecta jenensis is a quite common but nice small jewel among crustose, saxicolous (growing on rocks) lichens. It has waxy-looking, from pale or vividly yellow to deep orange apothecia with whitish, usually cracked to segments margins. The inconspicuous thallus is grayish with sometimes pink tint but often covered by dark layer of cyanobacteria, which makes its appearance black (Ref.:1). It is often found together with Trentepohlia aurea, an orange filamentous algae capable to live outside water (see orange tufts on pictures 11b and 12b). The photobiont of Gyalecta jenensis is also Trentepohlia algae. The lichen was in damp state when photographed. This species was photographed at this place almost exactly ten years ago.

Nikon D700 / Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8
results.location_name: Bovec basin, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia

Only a few spores observed, 6.5-7.5 × 4.5-5.5. Basidia up to 26.5×10, no sterigmata observed. It was hard to see any cells other than the hairs, and those were ~150×6.

I don’t believe this is L. villosa, but don’t have a better name. Hairs appear amyloid, which seems uncommon for cypheloid fungi. According to the key in Funga Nordica, all Lachnella species have basidia longer than 40 microns, which is another mismatch.

results.notes:
Growing on a cut Pinus log. Spores yellowish brown in water, smooth and thick-walled, seemed to be dextrinoid. Other structures inamyloid. Basidia 4-sterigmate. Monomitic. Individual spores: 11.97 × 7.12 µm, 14.08 × 7.61 µm, 15.77 × 8.13 µm, 11.36 × 6.67 µm, 13.15 × 7.54 µm, 12.64 × 6.87 µm, 13.39 × 7.16 µm, 12.65 × 6.67 µm, 14.78 × 7.43 µm, 13.44 × 7.69 µm, 12.30 × 6.56 µm, 14.50 × 6.82 µm, 12.54 × 6.48 µm, 11.89 × 6.81 µm, 12.71 × 6.95 µm, 12.83 × 6.99 µm, 13.42 × 8.09 µm, 14.74 × 7.21 µm, 14.53 × 7.40 µm, 12.53 × 6.86 µm

results.notes:
Unidentified lavender purple discoloration on Trametes betulina. (Fungal/bacterial??)
This fruit body of T. betulina was found on the same log as the ones in Obs. 308790. http://mushroomobserver.org/308790?q=EFht
It was near the ground but not on the ground a few inches up on the back side of the log. Lots of leaves and debris around it. It was the only specimen that I noticed had this purple discoloration to it. I have not been able to find anything that seems to match for this. I tried scoping a small piece of infected gill, but was unable to note anything that seemed particularly conclusive. I will continue to monitor other specimens in the area to see if this shows up on any other fruit bodies or if I can find some that may be more infected and taken over by this or in a more mature state.

results.notes:
On Juniperus virginiana.
I’ve found these in their mature stage before, but not a fresh specimen before it produced the little orange telial horns, so I figured I’d dissect one.
Flesh starts off mostly white but soon turning brown orange much like an apple that turns brown after you slice it. KOH on the inner flesh slowly turns a deep red and eventually black, FeSO4 on the flesh immediately turns dark green, NH4OH negative.
Flesh cells are rather large and variously shaped.
Teliospores are numerous, large, thickwalled, two chambered spores with a long “tail” on them.
Taste: Bitter

Habitat: natural tree hedge between abandoned pastures; moderately inclined mountain slope, south-east aspect; relatively warm and dry place; calcareous ground, sunny place; exposed to direct rain; average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 7-9 deg C, elevations 600 m (1.950 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: bark of smaller branches of almost stand-alone, recently cut down Juglans regia.

Place: Lower Trenta valley, right bank of river Soča; between villages Soča and Trenta; near Trenta 2b cottage, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC.

Comment: Candelariella xanthostigma is a tiny, common lichen. Its apothecia measure less than 1 mm in diameter. So, it is easy to overlook it. To use a hand lens for observation is a must. The species can be recognized by its yellow or yellow-greenish thallus, which consists of tiny corticated granules and yellow apothecia (if present). It grows on broadleaf tree bark. However, there exist several similar minute, yellow species, hence a mistake in determination cannot be excluded. Observing asci, which are 12- to 32-spored in Candelariella xanthostigma would make the determination reliable. Several specimens were found on this tree, mostly on thinner branches. Most of them were sterile (yellow granules only).

Nikon D700 / Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8

results.notes:
Growing side by side with Piloderma byssinum (Observation 308750) on the underside of a log which I cannot identify, but most likely it would be tanoak or redwood. Thin (less than 1mm), papery, removable.

Dimitic hyphal system with distinctly dextrinoid skeletal hyphae, which seems to determine the genus. Generative hyphae about 2.5 microns thick, skeletal ones about 2 microns. No clamps. Basidia 4-spored, 60-90 × 6-10. Spores 8.5-11 × 4-6, inamyloid. Gloeocystidia ~190×7, numerous.

Observation 63720 is probably the same fungus, apparently common in the San Fracisco Bay Area.

Code: Bot_1104/2018_DSC0175

Habitat: tree hedge between abandoned pastures; moderately inclined mountain slope, south-east aspect; relatively warm and dry place; calcareous ground, sunny place; exposed to direct rain; average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 7-9 deg C, elevations 600 m (1.950 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: bark of medium and small size branches of (almost) stand-alone, recently cut down Juglans regia.

Place: Lower Trenta valley, right bank of river Soča; between villages Soča and Trenta; near Trenta 2b cottage, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC.

Comment: Parmelina pastillifera is a small to middle-size but beautiful and conspicuous lichen. Its rosettes 2-7(10) cm in diameter are characteristic by its light mineral-gray to whitish appearance with blue tint, appressed to substrate lobes with a thin, dark edge and few short cilia. Thallus underside is black (but lighter near the edge) with crowded, simple, black rhizines. The species loves precipitations. So, no wander it feels well in Trenta valley with its about 3.000 mm (120 inches) of rain per year.

However, there exists another, more frequent species, Parmelina tiliacea, which is very similar to Parmelina pastillifera. It is practically impossible to distinguish both by habit only. In spite of this, they can be easily separated by observing their isidia (magnifying glass required). Both species have isidia when grown up. Parmelina pastillifera has black, button- or bun-shaped isidia, many of them are stalked. When they break off a small, white scar remains on the thallus surface (Ref.: 2) (see picture 7). On the other side Parmelina tiliacea has dark brown, cylindrical or coralloid isidia. Both species are rather rare and on the Red List at least in Germany (Ref.:5). In this observation many specimens were growing on branches (having 2–4 cm in diameter) of this tree. All of them were sterile (without apothecia), which is almost always the case.

Nikon D700 / Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8

Odorless, or essentially so, when picked and none upon drying.
Cap pale rose to deep pink with light yellow disc, dry and smooth. Wrinkly, but not truly striated. Cap, gills and stipe not bruising. Quite small. Cap only peeling near margin, but there easily.
Gills not anastomosing, yellow becoming browner with age, starting at the cap margin. Pale white cream near apex of stipe and probably original color.
Stipe bright white, smooth and unchanging. Cylindrical and stuffed with rounded bulb at base. Longer than cap width.
Spores light yellow, warts of medium size and density, to maybe slightly tall. Isolated/no lines. Roughly 6.5×8 micros.
Taste weakly acrid at first, the acridity fading and becoming mild. Not bad.

results.notes:
I collected the specimen for Henry, but it was very delicate, and even though I was very careful and gentle, the cap has split apart into a few pieces. Unfortunately, there was only this one individual. We are having a record dry February and mushrooms are hard to come by. Mushroom was very smooth.

Upon drying, the gills have browned, with the cap remaining the same color.
Habitat: Tanbark oak and Douglas fir forest. Growing terrestrially. Site is on the top of a steep slope above Aptos Creek. Tanoak was the closest tree and logs.
GPS coordinates and elevation added.
Odor: This mushroom has a very weak and fairly mild odor. It is somewhat spermatic, perhaps slightly farinaceous. The odor was detected during collection and seems unchanged in scent or strength upon drying, but faded after about a week.

Any comments or opinions are welcome.

results.notes:
Code: Bot_1102/2018_9749, Bot_1104/2018_DSC0127, Bot_1105/2018_DSC0357, Bot_1113/2018_DSC1001

Habitat: tree hedge between abandoned pastures; moderately inclined mountain slope, south-east aspect; relatively warm and dry place; calcareous ground, sunny place; exposed to direct rain; average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 7-9 deg C, elevations 600 m (1.950 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: bark of medium and small size branches of (almost) stand-alone, recently cut down Juglans regia.

Place: Lower Trenta valley, right bank of river Soča; between villages Soča and Trenta; near Trenta 2b cottage, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC.

Comment: Physconia distorta is a widespread and common foliose lichen growing almost on the whole world. After longer rains, when it is soaked with rain it is deep green and beautiful, while when dry, it is dark brown, brown-grayish or gray and much less attractive. The species can be recognized by: usually abundant apothecia (see Pic.3), thallus without soralia, soredia, maculae or cilia and abundant black, bottle-brush-like rhizines (see Pic.10) forming a dense mat on the underside of the thallus (see Pic.8). Thallus underside is dark in older parts but much lighter toward the edges and rhizines are almost simple on the thallus margins.
The upper canopy branches of the tree examined were full of specimens of this species. Pictures taken after several rainy days, except Pic.9 and 17, which show dry specimen.

Nikon D700 / Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8

results.notes:
Description of MHCB-16102903:

Pileus: 27 × 7 mm; plano-convex with decurved margin and low umbo; entirely velutinose, margin fimbriate; tad rugulose around the centre; brown, darker in centre, reddish hairs on outmost margin; margin exceeds lamellae.

Lamellae: L: 33, l: 1-3; barely touching the stipe, subdistand,; white; cystidia visible with 60x magn.

Stipe: 11 × 4-5 mm; central, compressed at apex, cilindrical otherwise; radicating; longitudinally striate, almost costate near root; entirely hispid with shourt hairs that are brown, but gradually become more red towards apex; reddish brown surface, more of a copper red at apex.

Context: Tough, quite flexible in both stipe and pileus, fairly distinct grooved in apex; firm and solid; white throughout.

Smell/Taste: None to very faint spicy smell; mild, slightly “dark” flavour.

Microscopy: None done

Ecology: Associated with Quercus on mesotrophic, loamy soil, old lane.

Notes: Dessicates very well, keeping most of its stature and colours. Beautiful mushroom!

Habitat: pasture, in limestone area. Fairy ring diameter about 7 m. Cap diameters up to 15 cm. Very mature specimens.

Considered species: Lepista sp. (e.g. Lepista personata), Volvopluteus gloiocephalus.

I think these are old Sarcomyxa serotina? They were about 2cm wide and were growing on a rotting log in a mixed, but mostly oak forest.
Yellow and white fungus growing on a cut log – most likely pine. On the edge of a meadow that separates a pine forest from a mostly deciduous (oak) forest.
1-3mm on decorticated, rotting wood in a mostly deciduous forest.

Cap: 10-12cm wide
7-8 cm deep
10-30mm thick
Stem: 10-11cm long
9-20mm thick. Wider at base.
Color: orange red/ orange/ purplish-orange-brown/ maroon. Color of stem is darker than cap and is maroon in color.
Flesh: hard. Inner flesh color is brown.

Growing at the base of a dead fallen hardwood. (Likely maple.)
